headline.main: A Cuisine With a Diversity of Tastes

docs.abstract: Stephanie Lyness reviews Gunung Tahan, Malaysian restaurant in New Haven; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: HERE I am, paddling around in another Asian cuisine. This time it is Malaysian at the small restaurant Gunung Tahan (which means Tahan Mountain, the highest mountain in Malaysia), situated in a shopping mall on the border of New Haven and Woodbridge. This restaurant is a real find, in part because the food is very good, but also for its rarity. I know of only one other Malaysian restaurant in the state.

headline.main: Middle Eastern Cuisine for the Adventurous

docs.abstract: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Aladdin, Middle Eastern restaurant in Syosset, NY (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE new Aladdin restaurant is a stylish surprise in a storefront at the far end of the Syosset Plaza at 629 Jericho Turnpike, Syosset (921-7777). It is ideal for diners who seek adventurous eating. The food, billed as fine Middle Eastern cuisine, is a vibrant melange of the dishes of Greece, Morocco and Turkey, among others, prepared by Iranian chefs, sometimes with an unexpectedly sweet spin. This sleek, serene, wood paneled place, with its discreet lighting, fresh flowers, plants, white tablecloths and mirrors topped by onion dome frames, is considerably more elaborate than most Middle Eastern shopping center eateries.

headline.main: To Rainbow Cuisine Via Warthog Pate

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Delegates Dining Room at the United Nations is host to a culinary safari this month. Through March 29, chefs representing the South African Chefs Association are preparing menus of specialties like kudu medallions, ostrich pastrami, loin of springbok, warthog pate, Malay pickled fish and malva pudding. Dishes like warthog pate are new, an example of a concept South Africans are calling rainbow cuisine. They are trying to weave a culinary identity from the ingredients and cultural strands -- Xhosa, Zulu, Dutch, English, Portuguese, German, Indian, Malay, French and others -- that have shaped the country for more than 300 years.

headline.main: A Nonintimidating Spot for Thai Cuisine

docs.lead_paragraph: LONG ISLAND is not fertile ground for Thai food. From the Queens line to Montauk Point, or more accurately from Seeda in Valley Stream to Chinda's in Sag Harbor, the Island can claim fewer than a dozen Thai restaurants. Visitors from the West Coast, who are used to Thai restaurants on just about every other corner, are surprised by their scarcity here. For Long Islanders who cut their baby teeth on Chinese food and order sushi with aplomb, Thai food is still an adventure.

headline.main: Quebec's Cuisine: With a Lighter Ladle

docs.lead_paragraph: OLD QUEBEC, with its clusters of lovingly restored buildings from the 17th and 18th centuries, horse-drawn carriages and streets lined with antique shops, is a city rooted in the past. But increasingly its restaurants are thoroughly up to date, turning from traditional fare to accommodate contemporary tastes. Often this has meant that popular places with tourist menus now feature lasagna and pizza along with bistro boilerplate like onion soup and coq au vin. But there is cooking done with a lighter hand, too, with an emphasis on market-fresh ingredients, and sometimes even a stylish whiff of Asia on the plate.

headline.main: CUISINE OF INDIA, TROLLEYS IN HONOLULU

docs.lead_paragraph: A Tasting Tour From Kashmir To Madras Stretching from the lakes of Kashmir in the north to the seaside resort of Fisherman's Cove in the south, and proceeding by jet aircraft, by rowboat along the Ganges River and by elephant to the Amber Fort in Jaipur, tours of India are scheduled this fall with primary focus on the nation's rich cuisine. Participants will observe the preparation of dishes such as dhansak (a spicy lentil and meat dish from Bombay), Mughlai curries and tandoori chicken and lamb as well as lotus-root curry as served aboard the houseboats of Kashmir. And they will receive lessons in the vegetarian cooking of Madras. During the 21-day tours, which leave Oct. 9 and Nov. 1, accommodations will be in the Taj Hotels, where chefs will teach Indian cooking in the kitchens, often after visits to markets and spice shops for selection of ingredients. Visiting such sites as Srinagar, Delhi, Varanasi, Khajuraho, Agra, Jaipur and Madras, the tour is priced at $3,925 a person in double occupancy, from New York or Los Angeles. The price includes international round-trip air fare, air fare within India, all land arrangements, accommodations, daily breakfast and dinner and some lunches, sightseeing (with English-speaking guides), entrance fees, guide services, and transfers.

headline.main: RENAISSANCE IN SPAIN LIGHTENS THE CUISINE

docs.lead_paragraph: WHILE Americans are embracing traditional Spanish foods such as paella and gazpacho, Spaniards are increasingly turning to something else. Many are calling it new Spanish cuisine. There is no one definable taste or method. It is more a process, begun a decade ago and steadily growing, to lighten food while maintaining flavor, sometimes clear and simple, sometimes rich and earthy. ''A great rennaissance is under way in Spanish cooking,'' said Inaki Oyarbide, chef at Principe de Viana, a popular Madrid restaurant and one of the pacesetters. ''It is part of the great social and cultural changes taking place all over Spain.'' The new Spanish cuisine includes dishes such as Mr. Oyarbide's baked hake sitting atop a pureed green bell pepper sauce, a modern version of a hake and sliced peppers preparation. Or there is oxtail with a sage-flavored sauce of pureed green beans, leeks, onions and swiss chard, all favorite Spanish ingredients but traditionally used in more stewlike dishes. Pedro Larumbe, the chef of Cabo Mayor in Madrid and winner of the 1985 Ministry of Culture prize as Spain's best chef, serves new-style specialties such as quail in a refined version of Spanish escabeche, a mixture of olive oil, wine vinegar, onions, thyme and toasted bay leaves more often used to marinate fish fillets.

headline.main: A TRADE SCHOOL TEACHES FRENCH CUISINE

docs.lead_paragraph: IN an age when renowned chefs are objects of the sort of hero worship formerly accorded only to statesmen, artists and athletes, it is somewhat jarring to hear Dorothy Cann's assessment of the culinary profession. ''The discipline that goes into learning cooking is the same as that for learning welding,'' Miss Cann, who runs a trade school, said recently, adding as an afterthought: ''I don't want to put down cooking in any way because, of course, it is very much a creative profession. But at the same time it is a trade, and that's how you should learn it.'' Miss Cann, by her own admission, is more comfortable with a blowtorch than a boning knife. Since 1978 she has been director of the Apex Technical School, one of the largest trade schools in the country. Apex offers courses in welding, air-conditioning, refrigeration, auto mechanics and auto body repair.

headline.kicker: COLD FOOD FOR THE TORID DAYS OF SUMMER
headline.main: NOUVELLE CUISINE INSPIRES SALADS AS CENTERPIECES

docs.lead_paragraph: THE salad has come a long way lately in this country. To realize just how far, you need only glance back at the typical restaurant menu of a few years ago, where either a fruit salad (one of gastronomy's more forgettable items) or that unsophisticated blend of apples, walnuts, celery and mayonnaise known as Waldorf salad was bound to appear. For green salads, the standard item was iceberg lettuce. There were exceptions: some decent and substantial seafood and poultry salads such as lobster, crab, shrimp and chicken. And there was the ubiquitous chef's salad with its combination of ham, cheese, chicken and hard-cooked eggs. But it was the arrival of nouvelle cuisine that rescued the salad. With its emphasis on light, colorful, imaginative ideas, nouvelle opened up a new array of possibilities. Sauteed goose liver on a bed of greens, dressed with walnut or hazelnut oil and raspberry vinegar, is just one example of how far a salad can go when its maker decides to pull out a few stops.
